intro: Lepidium bidentatum var. remyi, commonly known as the Mexican toothplant, is a herbaceous plant native to Mexico and parts of Central America. It belongs to the Brassicaceae family, which includes many economically important crops such as cabbage and mustard. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, featuring slender stems and small, lance-shaped leaves. Its flowers are white or pale yellow, arranged in clusters, and it produces small, round, yellowish seeds. The plant is characterized by its unique, tooth-like structures on its leaves, which give it its common name.
